transcript:
Patient: One accomplishment I included on my list was completing a challenging assignment for my PhD program. I received positive feedback from my professor, which felt really good. Another accomplishment was reaching out to a classmate and asking if they wanted to form a study group. It was difficult for me to take that step, but I'm glad I did because it's helped me feel more connected and supported in my academic pursuits.

Therapist: Those are significant accomplishments, Maria. Completing a challenging assignment and receiving positive feedback is a testament to your hard work and dedication. It's also great to hear that you took the initiative to form a study group. Reaching out to others and building connections can be difficult, especially when you're feeling down, but it's an essential step in combating depression. How did referring to your list of accomplishments help you when you were feeling down?

Patient: When I'm feeling down, it's easy for me to get stuck in a negative thought pattern, focusing on my perceived failures and shortcomings. Referring to my list of accomplishments helps me break that cycle and reminds me that I am capable of achieving great things. It also helps me put my negative thoughts into perspective and recognize that they don't define me.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Maria. Using your list of accomplishments to break the cycle of negative thoughts and gain perspective is a powerful tool. It's a way of challenging the negative beliefs you hold about yourself and reinforcing more balanced and realistic beliefs. You mentioned that practicing self-compassion has been more challenging for you. Can you share a specific situation where you tried to practice self-compassion and how it felt?

Patient: Last week, I received a lower grade than I expected on an assignment. My initial reaction was to criticize myself harshly, thinking that I wasn't smart enough or dedicated enough to succeed in my program. I caught myself engaging in this negative self-talk and tried to practice self-compassion by asking myself what I would say to a friend in the same situation. I imagined telling a friend that one grade doesn't define their worth or intelligence and that it's an opportunity to learn and grow. However, applying that same compassion to myself felt foreign and uncomfortable.

Therapist: It's common for people to find it easier to extend compassion to others than to themselves, especially if they're used to being self-critical. The fact that you were able to catch your negative self-talk and attempt to practice self-compassion is a significant step forward. It's okay if it feels foreign and uncomfortable at first; that's a sign that you're challenging long-held beliefs and patterns. With practice, self-compassion will become more natural and automatic. Let's explore the connection between your negative self-talk and your core beliefs. When you criticize yourself for receiving a lower grade than expected, what underlying beliefs might be fueling that criticism?

Patient: I think the underlying belief is that I'm not good enough. I have this idea that I need to be perfect in order to be worthy of love and acceptance. Anything less than perfection feels like a failure, and I worry that others will see me as incompetent or unworthy.

Therapist: Thank you for sharing that, Maria. The belief that you're not good enough is a common core belief that many people struggle with, and it can fuel a lot of negative self-talk and self-criticism. This belief likely developed over time, perhaps through experiences in your childhood or past relationships, and it's become a deeply ingrained part of how you view yourself. In CBT, we work on identifying and challenging these core beliefs, as they often contribute to feelings of depression and anxiety. One way to challenge this belief is to gather evidence that contradicts it. For example, you mentioned that you received positive feedback from your professor on a challenging assignment. How does that feedback fit with the belief that you're not good enough?

Patient: When I really think about it, the positive feedback from my professor does contradict the belief that I'm not good enough. It shows that I am capable of producing quality work and that my efforts are recognized and appreciated by others. However, it's difficult for me to fully accept and internalize that evidence because the negative belief is so strong.

Therapist: That's a great observation, Maria. Even when we have evidence that contradicts our negative core beliefs, it can be difficult to fully accept and internalize that evidence because the beliefs are so deeply ingrained. That's why challenging core beliefs is a gradual process that requires consistent practice and effort. One technique we can use to gather evidence against your negative core belief is the Positive Data Log. This involves keeping a record of experiences and interactions that provide evidence against the belief that you're not good enough. For example, you could write down positive feedback you receive, moments when you feel connected to others, or times when you accomplish something you're proud of. By actively looking for and recording this evidence, you can start to build a more balanced and realistic view of yourself. How do you feel about trying this technique?

Patient: I'm willing to give it a try. I can see how gathering evidence against my negative core belief could help me develop a more balanced view of myself. It's just hard to break out of the habit of focusing on my perceived flaws and failures.

Therapist: I understand that it's a challenging habit to break, but with consistent practice and effort, it is possible to shift your focus and develop a more balanced view of yourself. Remember that you don't have to do this alone; I'm here to support you every step of the way. As you work on your Positive Data Log, it can also be helpful to practice self-compassion when you notice yourself engaging in negative self-talk. Instead of criticizing yourself, try to speak to yourself with the same kindness and understanding that you would offer to a friend. This might feel uncomfortable at first, but with practice, it will become more natural. Let's set a goal for you to record at least three pieces of evidence in your Positive Data Log each day and to practice self-compassion whenever you notice negative self-talk. How does that sound?

Patient: That sounds manageable. I'll make a conscious effort to record evidence in my Positive Data Log and to practice self-compassion when I notice myself being self-critical. It's going to take time and practice, but I'm committed to working on developing a more balanced view of myself.

Therapist: That's great, Maria. Remember that progress isn't always linear, and there will be ups and downs along the way. The important thing is that you keep practicing and don't give up on yourself. In addition to the Positive Data Log and self-compassion practice, another technique we can use to challenge your negative core belief is cognitive restructuring. This involves identifying negative thoughts, evaluating the evidence for and against those thoughts, and generating more balanced and realistic alternative thoughts. For example, if you notice yourself thinking, "I'm not good enough," you could evaluate the evidence for and against that thought and generate an alternative thought like, "I am capable and worthy, even if I'm not perfect." How do you feel about incorporating cognitive restructuring into your practice?

Patient: Cognitive restructuring makes sense to me, and I can see how it could be helpful in challenging my negative thoughts and beliefs. It's just a matter of catching those thoughts when they happen and taking the time to evaluate them and generate alternatives.

Therapist: You're right, Maria. Catching negative thoughts and taking the time to evaluate them and generate alternatives is a skill that requires practice. One way to make it easier is to set aside a specific time each day to reflect on your thoughts and practice cognitive restructuring. This could be in the morning, before bed, or any other time that works for you. You could also try setting a reminder on your phone or using a journal to help you stay accountable. Remember that you don't have to do this perfectly; the goal is simply to start noticing your thoughts and questioning their validity. With practice, it will become more automatic.
